node.plaintext:
https://neo4j.com/blog/scale-out-neo4j-using-apache-mesos-and-dc-os/



https://www.r-bloggers.com/presenting-survey-data/



Quantifying stuff has a reputation for creating absurdities.  Some would say
that other methods create an equal number of absurdities, except they're just
way harder to see.
http://andrewgelman.com/2018/07/03/flaws-stupid-horrible-algorithm-revealed-made-numerical-predictions/



https://flowingdata.com/2018/06/28/why-people-make-bad-charts-and-what-to-do-when-it-happens/



https://github.com/solid/solid

https://flowingdata.com/2018/06/28/why-people-make-bad-charts-and-what-to-do-when-it-happens/

https://hbr.org/2018/07/if-you-say-something-is-likely-how-likely-do-people-think-it-is

One of the best-written tutorials I've ever seen:
https://jacobbuckman.com/post/tensorflow-the-confusing-parts-1/
